paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Whether the strongly irradiated, likely tidally locked rocky exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b retains an atmosphere, based on JWST phase-curve spectroscopy and atmospheric retrievals.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed TRAPPIST-1 b phase-curve dataset
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One rocky exoplanet observed with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy across orbital phase measuring thermal phase variation and spectral structure near the 15 um CO2 band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere-free model representing minimal heat redistribution, used as a null case for evaluating whether data require atmospheric transport and absorption.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere-bearing retrieval family with significant CO2 absorption that is tested against observed phase behavior and 15 um spectral structure.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmospheric scenario with weaker CO2-signature constraints that remains considered in the inference because current data do not fully exclude it.

major_limitations: Single-planet evidence cannot establish atmospheric prevalence for all rocky M-dwarf planets.
Retrieval assumptions about circulation, opacity priors, and cloud treatment materially affect posterior estimates.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral-feature inference.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
